00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserParametricLine.pl - Implements Formulas that represent parametric lines.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This is a Parser class that implements parametric lines as
00024 a subclass of the Formula class.  The standard ->cmp routine
00025 will work for this, provided we define the compare() function
00026 needed by the overloaded ==.  We assign the special precedence
00027 so that overloaded operations will be promoted to the ones below.
00028 
00029 Use ParametricLine(point,vector) or ParametricLine(formula)
00030 to create a ParametricLine object.  You can pass an optional
00031 additional parameter that indicated the variable to use for the
00032 parameter for the line.
00033 
00034 Usage examples:
00035 
00036     $L = ParametricLine(Point(3,-1,2),Vector(1,1,3));
00037     $L = ParametricLine([3,-1,2],[1,1,3]);
00038     $L = ParametricLine("<t,1-t,2t-3>");
00039 
00040     $p = Point(3,-1,2); $v = Vector(1,1,3);
00041     $L = ParametricLine($p,$v);
00042 
00043     $t = Formula('t'); $p = Point(3,-1,2); $v = Vector(1,1,3);
00044     $L = ParametricLine($p+$t*$v);
00045 
00046     Context()->constants->are(a=>1+pi^2); # won't guess this value
00047     $L = ParametricLine("(a,2a,-1) + t <1,a,a^2>");
00048 
00049 Then use
00050 
00051    ANS($L->cmp);
00052 
00053 to get the answer checker for $L.
00054 
00055 =cut
00056 
00057 loadMacros('MathObjects.pl');
00058 
00059 sub _parserParametricLine_init {ParametricLine::Init()}; # don't reload this file
00060 
00061 #
00062 #  Define the subclass of Formula
00063 #
00064 package ParametricLine;
00065 our @ISA = qw(Value::Formula);
00066 
00067 sub Init {
00068   my $context = $main::context{ParametricLine} = Parser::Context->getCopy("Vector");
00069   $context->{name} = "ParametricLine";
00070   $context->variables->are(t=>'Real');
00071   $context->{precedence}{ParametricLine} = $context->{precedence}{special};
00072   $context->reduction->set('(-x)-y'=>0);
00073 
00074   main::Context("ParametricLine");  ### FIXME:  probably should require author to set this explicitly
00075 
00076   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub ParametricLine {ParametricLine->new(@_)}');
00077 }
00078 
00079 sub new {
00080   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00081   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00082   my ($p,$v,$line,$t);
00083   return shift if scalar(@_) == 1 && ref($_[0]) eq $class;
00084   $_[0] = $context->Package("Point")->new($context,$_[0]) if ref($_[0]) eq 'ARRAY';
00085   $_[1] = $context->Package("Vector")->new($context,$_[1]) if ref($_[1]) eq 'ARRAY';
00086   if (scalar(@_) >= 2 && Value::classMatch($_[0],'Point') &&
00087                          Value::classMatch($_[1],'Vector')) {
00088     $p = shift; $v = shift;
00089     $t = shift || $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,'t');
00090     $line = $p + $t*$v;
00091   } else {
00092     $line = $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,shift);
00093     Value::Error("Your formula doesn't look like a parametric line")
00094       unless $line->type eq 'Vector' || $line->type eq "Point";
00095     $t = shift || (keys %{$line->{variables}})[0];
00096     Value::Error("A line can't be just a constant vector") unless $t;
00097     $p = $context->Package("Point")->new($context,$line->eval($t=>0));
00098     $v = $context->Package("Vector")->new($context,$line->eval($t=>1) - $p);
00099     Value::Error("Your formula isn't linear in the variable %s",$t)
00100       unless $line == $p + $context->Package("Formula")->new($context,$t) * $v;
00101   }
00102   Value::Error("The direction vector for a parametric line can't be the zero vector")
00103     if ($v->norm == 0);
00104   $line->{p} = $p; $line->{v} = $v;
00105   $line->{isValue} = $line->{isFormula} = 1;
00106   return bless $line, $class;
00107 }
00108 
00109 =head2 $lhs == $rhs
00110 
00111  #
00112  #  Two parametric lines are equal if they have
00113  #  parallel direction vectors and either the same
00114  #  points or the vector between the points is
00115  #  parallel to the (common) direction vector.
00116  #
00117 
00118 =cut
00119 
00120 sub compare {
00121   my ($self,$l,$r) = Value::checkOpOrderWithPromote(@_);
00122   my ($lp,$lv) = ($l->{p},$l->{v});
00123   my ($rp,$rv) = ($r->{p},$r->{v});
00124   return $lv <=> $rv unless ($lv->isParallel($rv));
00125   return 0 if $lp == $rp || $lv->isParallel($rp-$lp);
00126   return $lp <=> $rp;
00127 }
00128 
00129 sub cmp_class {'a Parametric Line'};
00130 sub showClass {shift->cmp_class};
00131 
00132 sub cmp_defaults {(
00133   shift->SUPER::cmp_defaults,
00134   showEqualErrors => 0,  # don't show problems evaluating student answer
00135   ignoreInfinity => 0,   # report infinity as an error
00136 )}
00137 
00138 #
00139 #  Report some errors that were stopped by the showEqualErrors=>0 above.
00140 #
00141 sub cmp_postprocess {
00142   my $self = shift; my $ans = shift;
00143   my $error = $self->context->{error}{message};
00144   $self->cmp_error($ans)
00145     if $error =~ m/^(Your formula (isn't linear|doesn't look)|A line can't|The direction vector)/;
00146 }
00147 
00148 1;
